text: [Music]
[Music]
[Applause]
I'm standing in front of you today in
all humility wanting to share with you
my journey of the last 6 years in the
field of service and education.
You know, I'm not a trained academic and
neither am I a veteran social worker. I
was 26 years in the corporate world
trying to make organizations profitable.
And then in
2003, I started Parika Humanity
Foundation from my kitchen table. The
first thing that we did was walked
through the slums. You know, by the way,
there are two million people uh in in
Bangalore who live in 800 slums. We
couldn't go to all the uh slums, but we
tried to cover as much as we could. We
walked through these slums, identified
houses where children would never go to
school. We talked to the parents, tried
to convince them uh about sending their
children to school. We played with the
children and came back home really
tired, exhausted, but im with images of
bright faces, twinkling eyes and went to
sleep. We were all excited to start, but
the numbers hit us then. 200 million
children between 4 to 14 that should be
going to school but do not. 100 million
children that who go to school but
cannot read 125 million who cannot uh do
basic maths. We also heard that 250
billion Indian rupees was dedicated for
government schooling. 90% that was spent
on uh teacher salary and administrator
salary and yet India has nearly the uh
the highest teacher absentism in the in
the world with one out of four teachers
not going to school at all the entire
academic year. Those numbers were
absolutely
mind-boggling, overwhelming. And we were
constantly asked when will you start,
how many schools will you start, how
many children will you get, uh how are
you going to scale, uh how are you going
to
replicate? It was very difficult not to
get scared, not to get daunted. But we
dug our heels and said, "We're not in
the number game.
We want to take one child at a time and
take the child right through school,
send to college and get them prepared
for better living, a high valued
job. So we started uh Parika the first
paricramma school started in a slum
where there are about 70,000 chu uh
people living uh below the poverty line.
Uh we start our first school was on a
rooftop uh of a building inside the
slums a second story building only
secondstory building inside the slums
and that roof uh a rooftop did not have
uh any ceiling only only half a tin
sheet that was our first school 165
children Indian academic year begins in
June so June it rains so many at times
all of us would be huddled under the
twin roof uh waiting for the rain to
stop. My god, what a bonding exercise
that
was. And all of us that were under that
roof are still here together today. Then
came the second school, the third
school, the fourth school and a junior
college. In six years now, we have four
schools. uh one junior college, 1,100
children coming from 28 slums and four
[Applause]
orphanages. Our dream is very simple. To
send each of these kids, get them
prepared to live to be educated but also
to live peacefully contented in this
conflictridden chaotic globalized world.
Now when you talk global you have to
talk English and so all our schools are
English medium schools. But then you
know there's this myth that children
from the slums uh cannot uh speak
English well. No one in their family
spoken English. No one in their
generation speak spoken English. But how
wrong it is. I like adventurous books.
Um and one of my favorites are like
Alfred Hitchcock and the three
investigators Hardy Boys and Hollywood.
Um all those three are like although
they are like in different context, one
is like magical, the other two are like
investigation. Um I like those books
because they have something special in
them. The vocabulary used in those books
and the way the style of writing I mean
like once I pick up one book I cannot
put it down till I finish the whole
book. It's like even if it takes me like
4 and 1/2 hours or 3 and 1/2 hours to
finish my I do it. I did a Google search
and I got the information about world's
fastest cars. I like
uh Ducati Zz 143 because it is the
fastest which is the world's fastest
bike and I like Pa 220 DTS DTSI because
it is India's fastest bike.
Well, um the girl that you saw, uh her
father sells flowers on the roadside and
this little boy has been coming to
school for 5 years. But isn't it strange
that little boys all over the world love
fast
bikes? He hasn't seen one. He hasn't
ridden one, of course, but he has done a
lot of research through Google search.
you know um when we started with our
English medium schools we also decided
to adopt the best curriculum possible
the ICS curriculum and again there were
people who laughed at me and said don't
be crazy choosing such a tough
curriculum for these children they'll
never be able to
cope not only do our children cope very
well but they excel in it you should
just come across to see how well our
children
do there's also This myth that parents
from uh the slums are not interested in
their children going to school. They'd
much rather put them to work. That's
absolute hogwash. All parents all over
the world want their children to lead a
better life than themselves. But they
need to believe that change is possible.
Mommy, daddy.
um we have 80% attendance uh for all our
parents teachers meeting sometimes it's
even 100% much more than many privileged
schools um fathers have started to
attend you know it's very interesting
when we started our schools are uh the
parents would give thumbrints for in the
attendance register. Now they have
started writing their signature. The
children have taught them. It's amazing
how much children can teach. Um we have
a few months ago actually uh late last
year uh we had a few mothers who came to
us and said uh you know we want to learn
how to read and write. Can you teach us?
So we started an afterchool for our
parents for our mothers. We had 25
mothers who came regularly after school
to um study and we want to continue with
this program and extended to all our
other
schools. 98% of our fathers are
alcoholics. So you can imagine how
traumatized and how dysfunctional the
houses are where our children come from.
We have to send the fathers to uh de
addiction uh labs and when they come
back most times sober we have to find uh
a job for them so that they don't
regress. We have about three fathers who
have been trained to cook have we have
uh taught them nutrition hygiene we have
helped them set up their kitchen and now
they are supplying food to our children.
They do a very good job because their
children are eating their food. But most
importantly, this is the first time that
they have got respect and they feel that
they're doing something worthwhile. More
than 90% of our non-eing staff are all
parents and extended families. We've
started many programs just to make sure
that the child comes to school. Um
vocational skill program for the older
siblings. So the younger ones are not
stopped from coming to school. There's
also this myth that children from the
slums cannot integrate with
mainstream. Uh take a look at this
little girl who was one of the 28
children from all privileged schools
best schools in the city in the country
that was selected for the Duke
University talent identification program
and was sent to I am Ahmedabad. Juke IMA
camp. Whenever we say that I am it was
such a pride for us to go into that camp
itself and we went there everybody were
very friendly especially we I got a lot
of lot of friends and I felt that my
English has improved a lot going there
and chatting with friends and all those
there uh the we met a children who are
with a different uh uh different
standard and all those different mindset
a totally different society and I I
mingled with almost with everyone They
were very friendly. I had a very good
friends there uh who are from Delhi, who
are from Mumbai. Uh even now we are in
Tina through Facebook. After this uh
Abadabata trip, I've been like totally
different like migling with our people
and all this. Before that I wasn't I
feel I feel I wasn't like this. I don't
even mingle. I start speaking with
someone so quickly and I know my uh
accent with the English and all this
improved a lot and I learned football,
volleyball, uh frisbee, lots of games. I
I wouldn't want to go to Bangalore. Let
me stay here. Such a beautiful food. I
enjoy eating food. It is so beautiful. I
enjoyed eating food. Like
ask beer will come and ask me yes ma'am
what you want? It is so good to
[Applause]
hear
this this girl was working as a maid
before she came to school and today she
wants to be a
neurologist. Um we have a our children
are doing brilliantly in sports. Uh they
are really excelling. There's an
interchool uh athletic competition that
is held every year every every year uh
in Bangalore where 5,000 children
participate uh from 140 best schools in
the city. Our children are we've got the
best school award for three years
successively and our children are coming
back home with bag full of medals but
lots of admirers and friends. Uh there
were last year there were a couple of
kids from elite schools that came to ask
for admissions in our school. We also
have our own very own dream team. Why is
this happening? Why is this confidence?
Is it the exposure? We have professors
from MIT, Berkeley, Stanford, uh Indian
Institute of Science who come and teach
our children lots of scientific
formulas, experiments much beyond the
classroom. Art, music, uh are considered
therapy and uh mediums of expression. Uh
we also believe that you know it's the
content that is more important. It is
the it is the not the infrastructure,
not the toilets, not the libraries, but
it is what actually happens in the
school that is more important. The uh
creating an environment of learning of
of inquiry, of exploration is what is
true education. When we when we started
Paricramma, we had no idea which
direction we were taking. We didn't hire
McKenzie to do a business plan. Uh but
we we know for sure that what we want to
do today is is take one child at a time,
not get bogged with numbers and actually
see the child completes uh the circle of
life and unleashes the total potential.
Um we we do not believe in scale because
we believe in quality and scale and
numbers will automatically happen. We
have corporates that have stood behind
us and we are able to now open more
schools but we began with the idea of
one child at a time. This is 5-year-old
Parusharam. He was begging by a bus stop
a few years ago. got picked up and is
now in an orphanage. Has been coming to
school for the last four and a half
months. He's in kindergarten. He he has
learned how to speak English. We have a
model by which kids can speak English
and understand English in three and a
half 3 months time. I can tell you
stories uh in English of the thirsty
crow of the crocodile and of the
giraffe. And if you ask him what he
likes to do, he will say I like
sleeping. I like eating. I like playing.
And if you ask him what he wants to do,
he will say, I I want to horseing. Now,
horsing is going for a horse ride. So,
Parish comes to my office every day. He
comes for a tummy rub because he
believes that will give me luck. Uh when
I started Parika, I I uh began with a
great deal of arrogance of transforming
the world. But today, I have been
transformed. I have been changed with my
children. I have learned so much from
them. Love, compassion,
imagination and and and such creativity.
Uh Parisham is Parika with a simple
beginning but a long way to go. I
promise you Parisharam will uh speak in
the TED conference few years from now.
Thank
you.
